Our Constitution has enshrined equal protection under the law; making Juneteenth a federal holiday will give us all the opportunity to reflect on what that means and how to protect this principle for generations to come.
Slavery was a colossal evil, and inflicted great pain on Black Americans.

I love this great country of ours, & we have always shown an incredible capacity to learn from our mistakes and do what is right. As Pres George W. Bush said, "the price of our Union was America's original sin," and the fact is that our country didn't afford liberty to everyone.

After Confederate Gen. Lee surrendered, Union Gen. Gordon Granger's arrival in Galveston helped spread the message that war was over and enslaved people were free. Celebrations broke out among newly freed Black Americans in the south, & the day known as Juneteenth was born.

The Emancipation Proclamation didn't free all who were enslaved. It only applied to areas under Confederate control, not former Confederate territory that was taken by the Union or slave-holding border states.

The Emancipation Proclamation, issued two years earlier on January 1, 1863, established that all enslaved people "shall be then, thenceforward, and forever free." 

However, slavery remained relatively unhindered in Texas.
Juneteenth, recognized every year on 6/19, marks the day in 1865 when Union soldiers arrived in Galveston, TX, to take control of the state and ensure that enslaved people would be free.

[THREAD] I proudly voted to support making #Juneteenth a federal holiday. This day is central to U.S. history, the day the final enslaved Black Americans learned they had been freed. It's a celebration of liberty, freedom, & resilience in the face of the terrible evil of slavery. https://t.co/JRxdSCzu84

Minh‚Äôs dream for the future is that his daughter continues to thrive and that her children have access to a good education too. 

As for himself? ‚ÄúI look forward to retiring someday but I will stay in America. I like America.‚Äù

Immigrants come to our country seeking opportunity, but bring with them intelligence, creativity, innovation, and drive that makes our community stronger. It was an honor to meet Minh and share his #GA07ImmigrantStory.

In America, their daughter had the opportunity to receive a great public education, attend pharmacy school at the University of Georgia, and get her master‚Äôs degree ‚Äî opportunities afforded to them through careful saving, a manufacturing career, and hard work.

Five years after arriving in America, Minh took the test to become a citizen, and upon receiving his certificate, immediately started the process of sponsoring his wife to join him in America where they could start a family.

With a background in chemistry, Minh spent time innovating and exploring how they could use recycled plastics in their products to become more environmentally responsible. He helped recruit other Vietnamese immigrants, trained them, and today is Plant Manager.

Shortly after arriving, Minh began working a manufacturing job at AutoVentshade, now @LundInter. Two weeks were set aside for training, but Minh quickly learned the ropes in just two days. He has now worked at the company for 37 years.

In August of 1983, Minh made the tough decision to leave behind his family, friends, and new wife to find a better life for them. Alone with only $5 in his pocket, he started his journey through Thailand and Singapore to learn American culture, and was then sent to Atlanta.
Minh went on to earn a master‚Äôs degree in chemistry, and met his wife at the school where they both worked, but quickly realized that $10/month was not going to be enough to raise a family.

Minh grew up in Vietnam where he excelled academically, and was chosen from a highly selective process to attend college and study chemistry. After attaining his bachelor‚Äôs degree, he became a high school teacher in South Vietnam, earning $10 per month.

Representing the diverse communities of #GA07 is a privilege I‚Äôll never take for granted. During #ImmigrantHeritageMonth, I wanted to share some stories of the immigrants in our vibrant community, starting with Minh Trinh. THREAD ‚¨áÔ∏è https://t.co/POqNfsjKL8

I want to thank the co-leads of our would-be Censure Resolution for their work: Representatives @RepLindaSanchez @RepNikema and @RepLawrence.

I hope that Congress can take the necessary steps to serve as a model to a nation desperately in need of leaders willing to correct themselves when they are wrong, and to engage in a more civil discourse to ultimately work together toward a "more perfect union."
While I will certainly have vehement disagreements with Rep. Greene on policy, politics, and style...
Moving forward, I will continue to call out harmful or dangerous rhetoric by my colleagues, irrespective of which side of the aisle from which it emanates.
In light of her apology, I am electing not to go forward at this time with introducing a resolution of censure.

I was therefore pleasantly surprised to learn that she made the time to visit the Holocaust Memorial Museum (where I have the honor of serving as a trustee), and I appreciate that after her visit she understood the harm of her comparison and offered an apology.
After all, Rep. Greene has a long history of unapologetically inflammatory and dangerous rhetoric.

But when I heard Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene initial make her comparison of our nation‚Äôs Covid-response to the Holocaust, and then repeat it again and again, I never expected a retraction or an apology.
Sometimes we may stumble in our message. When we do, we should be given the chance to clarify exactly what we intended to say and promptly set the record straight.

I believe that words matter and that they have consequences. Elected officials, and especially members of Congress, have a great responsibility to carefully measure our words and be as precise as possible when we communicate.

I believe it is time for a course correction on U.S. policy toward Venezuela. It is time to stop using the well-being of the Venezuelan people as a bargaining chip.

The Biden administration must find other ways to pursue its foreign policy goals.

While U.S. officials debate the sanctions policy in Washington, for people in Venezuela the ongoing crisis is a life-and-death matter.

Sanctions should never be used to punish whole populations for the actions of their leaders or to bludgeon an adversary into submission.

Unlike smart sanctions that target the behavior of specific individuals, the impact of sectoral and secondary sanctions is indiscriminate, and purposely so.

The percentage of Venezuelans living in poverty increased from 48% in 2014 to 96% in 2019, with 80% in extreme poverty.
I am asking the Biden administration to lift all secondary and sectoral sanctions imposed on #Venezuela by the Trump Administration. https://t.co/6VDMir337L
